title: My friend is in university and taking a history class. The professor is using ChatGPT to write essays on the history topics and the students need to mark up its essays and point out where ChatGPT is wrong and correct it.

last_post.content:
Reddit: "My friend is in university and taking a history class. The professor is using ChatGPT to write essays on the history topics and the students need to mark up its essays and point out where ChatGPT is wrong and correct it."

https://old.reddit.com/r/ChatGPT/comments/117gtom/my_friend_is_in_university_and_taking_a_history/

Honestly, this is great! The students learn to check sources, discover that ChatGPT is unreliable, *and* can't use it to generate essay question answers for them, all at the same time!

title: Don't believe ChatGPT - we do NOT offer a "phone lookup" service

last_post.content:
We wrote a blog post about our on-going nightmare: ChatGPT recommends us for a service we don't provide.

Dozens of people are signing up to our site every day and then getting frustrated when "it doesn't work". Hugely frustrating.

https://blog.opencagedata.com/post/dont-believe-chatgpt

Please do NOT trust the nonsense ChatGPT spits out.

title: nature.com/articles/d41586-023...

last_post.content:
Many scholars are leaving Twitter for #Mastodon, a public, decentralized alternative, impervious to private take-over:

https://www.science.org/content/article/musk-reshapes-twitter-academics-ponder-taking-flight

Scholarly organizations are already supporting this migration:

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-00486-3

and

https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.7643817

There are analogous solutions for another public good in private hands: journals. There are even levers the scholarly community could pull to incentivize an analogous migration:

https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.5526634

What are we waiting for?

title: GitHub - chainsawriot/rang: Reconstructing R computational environments

last_post.content:
Excited to introduce the #Rstats package rang (developed by @chainsawriot and me). The pkg helps to reconstruct historical R environments to make old code run again (ie make it reproducible!). So far, it supports all code back to R 2.1.0 (2005!)
https://github.com/chainsawriot/rang


The package is an Rchaeological tool to ensure reproducibility retrospectively. You can also use rang to make your current projects future proof, but pkgs like renv or groundhog are better suited for this task.

title: Parachute use to prevent death and major trauma when jumping from aircraft: randomized controlled trial

last_post.content: There's a good deal of misinterpretation of a study that some suggest shows mask wearing doesn't make a difference. Before accepting something that flies in the face of a lot of evidence, it makes sense to look a study that shows parachute wearing has no impact on mortality when jumping from an airplane. https://www.bmj.com/content/363/bmj.k5094

title: Planning for AGI and beyond

last_post.content:
Human values are and will be embedded in "A.I.," "AGI," and every other technology we make, and so we must get right with the idea of being intentional about those values.

And that's about the extent of what i agree with in this naïvely utilitarian "AGI for the future" manifesto, with its "maximize the good and minimize the bad," its nebulous "widely and fairly shared" "benefits," and its frankly ableist verging on eugenical talk about how AGI will be another "point along the continuum of intelligence."

I just… These people are in charge of the manipulation and administration of billions of dollars worth of resources.

Why? Just why.

(I know why, but it's still damned dismaying.)
https://openai.com/blog/planning-for-agi-and-beyond/

title: Meetings *are* the work - Elizabeth Ayer - Medium

last_post.content:
I get deeply frustrated by the whole "meetings aren't real work" thing, and I needed to put out into the world why, so I could move on.

Eventually I got my thoughts together with help from Peter Drucker, Chris Argyris, Annie Duke, Jeff Bezos, Erika Hall, Mary Parker Follett, Samo Burja and Aristotle.

Just published: https://medium.com/@ElizAyer/meetings-are-the-work-9e429dde6aa3

title: https://findmycite.org

last_post.content:
I agree that a focus on product over process is often corrosive to learning,¹ but it seems that traditional grading regimes do more to promote this than generative AI. Also, it betrays a lack of imagination to suggest that these tools can’t put the focus on process.² Why aren’t the folks worrying about AI in education calling for a reassessment of assessment? That seems more inline w/ their stated goals. 🤔

____
¹ https://matthewbutterick.com/chron/camera-obscura-the-case-against-ai-in-classrooms.html h/t @dicthomson

² See e.g., https://findmycite.org

title: DensePose From WiFi

last_post.content:
Technology to recover peoples movements inside rooms from signals of ordinary WIFI routers seem to be advancing (still early phase though). I'm not super surprised but had not heard of this before. https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.00250 https://www.economist.com/science-and-technology/2023/01/25/wi-fi-signals-could-prove-useful-for-spies

Particularly enjoyed the sober conclusion in the latter article: ... [the scientists] talk of employing it to “monitor the well-being of elder people”. ... These ideas are, however, distractions from what any such system would almost certainly be used for to start with, namely surveillance.

#surveillance #machinelearning #ml #wifi

title: Taking stock of my

last_post.content:
Wrote a post this morning listing 12 software tools I use all the time as a #data journalist.

Because I wrote a recent post about #datasette and called it my data hammer, I decided to bash that metaphor into the ground, and called this collection of projects my "tool belt".

https://www.jeremiak.com/blog/data-toolbelt/

Do you use any of these tools in your day to day work? Love them? Hate 'em? I'm super curious to hear from you.

title: GitHub - crowding/async: Asynchronous programming for R -- async/await and generators/yield

last_post.content:
Just pushed to CRAN: release 0.3 of the #rstats async package, implementing generators, async/await and (now) streams for R.
https://github.com/crowding/async
New features include:
- Streams (async generators)
- Generator functions
- Delimited `goto()` within `switch()`
- Support for `on.exit` handlers
- Usability improvements, including single step debugging
- Expanded documentation
- Performance improvements (with more in the works)

title: Your ‘Simple Solution’ To Section 230 Is Bad: Julia Angwin Edition

last_post.content:
"Here’s where it’s important, yet again, to explain how #Section230 actually works. The fundamental point of Section 230 is to put the blame on the proper party: whoever is imbuing the content with whatever makes that content violate the law. That’s it.

The desire to blame websites because they haven’t managed to stop all humans from using their websites to do something bad, is such a weird obsession." @mmasnick
https://www.techdirt.com/2023/02/23/your-simple-solution-to-section-230-is-bad-julia-angwin-edition/

title: Netflix is Bringing Back Piracy

last_post.content:
I won't endorse piracy.

But on the one hand, look at the streaming media industry as a whole, probably at least at the second stage of what @pluralistic calls #enshittification -- raising prices, cutting free tiers, adding ads, walling up more content within greater numbers of providers.

On the other hand, look at internet piracy -- inexpensive, easy, relatively risk-free for the average consumer.

Compare the two, and it shouldn't be a surprise that piracy is booming.

https://www.disconnect.blog/p/netflix-is-bringing-back-piracy

title: Reduced, Reused and Recycled: The Life of a Dataset in Machine Learning Research

last_post.content:
The world according to the data #AI (#ML) sees.
50% of datasets are connected to 12 institutions.
Analysis of 4384 datasets and 60647 papers
Despite the foundational role of benchmarking practices in this field, relatively little attention has been paid to the dynamics of benchmark dataset use and reuse, within or across machine learning subcommunities
Read the report: Reduced, Reused and Recycled: The Life of a Dataset in Machine Learning Research
https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.01716

https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.10178

Lapuschkin, et al

Unmasking Clever Hans Predictors and Assessing What Machines Really Learn

This paper, though interesting, is limited to addressing only visual domains. Pixel relevance thus plays an outsize role in its treatment. A decent article to help counter ML hype, but not as strong as it could be.

See https://berryvilleiml.com/references/

title: Leading music genres among African Americans U.S. 2018 | Statista

last_post.content:
Happy #BlackHistoryMonth !

I will get to Black history. For now, I'm still on white US history.

Q: Why is so much Black music about violence and misogyny? I'm not racist, but I think Black culture is just more violent. Why does it seem that way?

A: Racism. Rap, trap, and drill, are only the most popular genres of Black music listened to *by white people.* The most popular among Black folk is R&B, almost 2X as popular. Violent rap is mostly for y'all.🤷🏿‍♂️

https://www.statista.com/statistics/945163/leading-music-genres-african-american/

#BlackMastodon

title: Donate - Open Web Advocacy

last_post.content:
The folks over at @owa are doing the most important work on and for the web right now. For several years they've been flat-out, full-time, without pay to make browser competition a reality on the mobile web.

Having achieved things I could have only hoped for 2 years ago (DMA mandates engine choice!), they're finally looking to raise a bit of cash to keep going.

If you work on the web, supporting them is an absolute no-brainer:

https://open-web-advocacy.org/donate/

LLaMA is a new *open-source*, high-performance large language model from Meta AI - FAIR.

title: pansharpening.md

last_post.content:
I was having unbidden pansharpening thoughts again, so I fixed typos and a pseudocode bug in my old 10,000 word gist on the topic: https://gist.github.com/celoyd/5bb5417b24801e0446ad5977cc3581e4

Proud to say that it’s the best non-academic introduction to the topic on the entire internet. Also, I admit, the worst, because it’s the only one. I don’t know why there aren’t more people interested in this.

title: Zombie newspaper sites, including Minneapolis' Southwest Journal, arise | MinnPost

last_post.content:
Thanks to #AI like #ChatGPT, welcome to “zombie #newspapers”:

“Minneapolis neighborhood newspaper the Southwest Journal shuttered at the end of 2020, but its web domain continues to post fresh content under the auspices of a Delaware ‘SEO company’ whose leader lives in Serbia.”

A few legacy articles under fictitious bylines still appear but recent posts are “junk content…to manipulate search engines.”

The new owner has “no interest in the #news business.”

#Journalism

https://www.minnpost.com/twin-cities-business/2023/02/zombie-newspaper-sites-including-minneapolis-southwest-journal-rise-from-grave/

title: Photospheric Variations: ambient sonification of sunspot data with Eurorack & Norns

last_post.content:
We did a little sonification of sunspot data over the last few hundred years. You can really hear the 11-year solar cycle! Made with the Loud Numbers norns script, and Eurorack.

title: Camera obscura: the case against AI in classrooms: Matthew Butterick

last_post.content:
I agree that a focus on product over process is often corrosive to learning,¹ but it seems that traditional grading regimes do more to promote this than generative AI. Also, it betrays a lack of imagination to suggest that these tools can’t put the focus on process.² Why aren’t the folks worrying about AI in education calling for a reassessment of assessment? That seems more inline w/ their stated goals. 🤔

____
¹ https://matthewbutterick.com/chron/camera-obscura-the-case-against-ai-in-classrooms.html h/t @dicthomson

² See e.g., https://findmycite.org

title: A dollar for your face: Meet the people behind Machine Learning models - AlgorithmWatch

last_post.content: Do you use a voice assistant? Do you like to add filters to your pictures? To make them, tech companies buy selfies and audio recordings from underpaid microworkers from poor countries like Venezuela or the Philippines. @algorithmwatch interviews #diplab researcher @ptubaro about the market for personal data that fuels AI. https://algorithmwatch.org/en/people-behind-machine-learning-models/

title: Predictive Text Encourages Predictable Writing

last_post.content:
@katestarbird We have controlled experiments showing half of the story:

Predictive text tools (e.g., most mobile keyboards) cause people to change content of what they write (word choices that are more "predictable" given the model used by predictive text and using fewer adjectives or other embellishments) compared to writing without predictive text.

http://www.eecs.harvard.edu/~kgajos/papers/2020/arnold20predictcive.shtml
